Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints and code scattered around me, the clock ticking louder with every passing minute. My phone buzzed with a message from my daughter: “Don’t forget, we’re all counting on you to help organize the family dinner this weekend. The kids can’t wait to see you!” I smiled, picturing my grandchildren’s faces, but my heart tightened. The holiday was always our time to reconnect, to share stories and laughter, and I knew how much it meant to everyone—especially after the year we’d had.

But my laptop chimed with another notification: a reminder from my project manager. The team was waiting on my core module, and without it, the entire build was at a standstill. The deadline loomed, and I could almost feel the weight of my colleagues’ expectations pressing down on me. They needed my expertise, my focus, my time—right now.

I stared at the family group chat, then at the lines of code on my screen, torn between the warmth of my family and the responsibility of my work. My mind raced, caught in the tug-of-war between being the grandparent my family needed and the engineer my team depended on.
